sub_topic: Numerical differentiation and integration using finite difference methods
message_1: Let f(x) = cos(x) and we want to approximate f'(x) using the forward difference formula with step size h = 0.1 at x = 0. Calculate the approximate value of f'(x) using this method.
message_2:
The forward difference formula is given by:

f'(x) ≈ (f(x + h) - f(x)) / h

In this case, f(x) = cos(x), x = 0, and h = 0.1. So we need to calculate f(0) and f(0.1) and then use the formula to approximate f'(x).

f(0) = cos(0) = 1
f(0.1) = cos(0.1) ≈ 0.995004

Now, we can use the forward difference formula:

f'(x) ≈ (f(0.1) - f(0)) / 0.1
f'(x) ≈ (0.995004 - 1) / 0.1
f'(x) ≈ -0.004996 / 0.1
f'(x) ≈ -0.04996

So, the approximate value of f'(x) using the forward difference formula with step size h = 0.1 at x = 0 is -0.04996.
